articles.headline: 14 Charged With Insider Trading in Galleon Case
articles.snippet: Federal prosecutors charged 14 hedge fund employees, lawyers and other investors in criminal complaints that seem to be connected to the Raj Rajaratnam case.
articles.abstract: Federal prosecutors charged 14 hedge fund employees, lawyers and other investors in criminal complaints that seem to be connected to the Raj Rajaratnam case.
articles.lead_paragraph: After weeks of speculation on Wall Street, prosecutors brought a fresh round of insider trading charges on Thursday that left no doubt they were aiming at hedge funds and the networks of market gossip that are endemic on trading floors.

articles.headline: Top Palestinian Rules Out Race for Re-election
articles.snippet: Mahmoud Abbas has threatened to resign before, but his statement showed his frustration with the state of Mideast diplomacy.
articles.abstract: Mahmoud Abbas has threatened to resign before, but his statement showed his frustration with the state of Mideast diplomacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank  The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, warned on Thursday that he would not seek re-election, the latest sign that the Obama administration’s drive to broker a Middle East peace accord, one of President Obama’s key foreign policy goals, has fallen into disarray.
articles.byline: By Ethan Bronner and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Army Doctor Held in Ft. Hood Rampage
articles.snippet: Military officials identified the suspect in the shootings as Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, a psychiatrist born in Virginia who reportedly was about to deploy overseas.
articles.abstract: Military officials identified the suspect in the shootings as Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, a psychiatrist born in Virginia who reportedly was about to deploy overseas.
articles.lead_paragraph: An Army psychiatrist facing deployment to one of America’s war zones killed 13 people and wounded 30 others on Thursday in a shooting rampage with two handguns at the sprawling Fort Hood Army post in central Texas, military officials said.

articles.headline: Goodbye to Reforms of 2002
articles.snippet: Congress is apparently gutting Sarbanes-Oxley, which required public companies to make sure their internal controls against fraud were not full of holes.
articles.abstract: Congress is apparently gutting Sarbanes-Oxley, which required public companies to make sure their internal controls against fraud were not full of holes.
articles.lead_paragraph: It took just five weeks after the WorldCom accounting scandal erupted in 2002 for Congress to pass, and President George W. Bush to sign, the Sarbanes-Oxley Act. That law required public companies to make sure their internal controls against fraud were not full of holes.

articles.headline: Suspect Was ‘Mortified’ About Deployment
articles.snippet: Having counseled scores of returning soldiers over combat stress, Major Hasan knew war’s realities, a cousin said.
articles.abstract: Having counseled scores of returning soldiers over combat stress, Major Hasan knew war’s realities, a cousin said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Born and reared in Virginia, the son of immigrant parents from a small Palestinian town near Jerusalem, he joined the Army right out of high school, against his parents’ wishes. The Army, in turn, put him through college and then medical school, where he trained to be a psychiatrist.

articles.headline: Reviews Raise Doubt on Training of Afghan Forces
articles.snippet: The U.S. program is struggling to help largely illiterate and often corrupt Afghan forces, documents suggest.
articles.abstract: The U.S. program is struggling to help largely illiterate and often corrupt Afghan forces, documents suggest.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  A series of internal government reviews have presented the Obama administration with a dire portrait of Afghanistan’s military and police force, bringing into serious question an ambitious goal at the heart of the evolving American war strategy  to speed up their training and send many more Afghans to the fight.
articles.byline: By Thom Shanker and John H. Cushman Jr

articles.headline: A Not-So-Guilty Pleasure
articles.snippet: Sales of footwear were up sharply in September and October, possibly because they are a less expensive way to indulge.
articles.abstract: Sales of footwear were up sharply in September and October, possibly because they are a less expensive way to indulge.
articles.lead_paragraph: For months now, consumers have been hunkering down in an economic storm, buying only what they need to survive, like groceries, diapers, medicine  and shoes.

articles.headline: New Drug for H1N1 Flu Offers Hope
articles.snippet: Peramivir might also be a life saver for its developer, BioCryst Pharmaceuticals, an unprofitable biotechnology company in Birmingham, Ala.
articles.abstract: Peramivir might also be a life saver for its developer, BioCryst Pharmaceuticals, an unprofitable biotechnology company in Birmingham, Ala.
articles.lead_paragraph: Athena Gurno thought her allergies were acting up when she started coughing in early October. But within days, Ms. Gurno, the 30-year-old mother of a young girl, was in a Seattle hospital, close to death from the H1N1 flu.

articles.headline:
A Scheme That Relied on Early Deal Tips,
With Touches From a James Bond Movie
articles.snippet: Prosecutors say a scheme brought in $20 million and relied on early tips about deals from the people involved in doing them, with the modern touch of disposable cellphones.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors say a scheme brought in $20 million and relied on early tips about deals from the people involved in doing them, with the modern touch of disposable cellphones.
articles.lead_paragraph: “We have become so paranoid for no reason,” the young trader told his friend in an evening call on his cellphone in late February 2008. There was always a reason to be paranoid, his friend responded, and they agreed to continue their talk at their Manhattan gym.

articles.headline: After Gruesome Find, Anger at Cleveland Police
articles.snippet: Residents near where 11 bodies were found in a house wonder why it took the police so long to investigate.
articles.abstract: Residents near where 11 bodies were found in a house wonder why it took the police so long to investigate.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND  After the third police station in a row refused to take a missing-person report about her niece two years ago, Sandy Drain took matters into her own hands.
articles.byline: By Ian Urbina and Christopher Maag

articles.headline: U.S. Unemployment Rate Hits 10.2%, Highest in 26 Years
articles.snippet: The number of unemployed rose to 15.7 million in October, as 190,000 nonfarm jobs were lost, the government said, and economists do not expect relief until next year.
articles.abstract: The number of unemployed rose to 15.7 million in October, as 190,000 nonfarm jobs were lost, the government said, and economists do not expect relief until next year.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the unemployment rate surged to 10.2 percent in October, reaching double digits for the first time in 26 years, it suddenly seemed possible that the nation might yet confront the worst joblessness since the Great Depression.

articles.headline: Army Tests Sole-Killer Theory as Details Emerge
articles.snippet: Officials were not prepared to say whether the attack was the act of a lone and troubled man or connected to terrorist groups, foreign or domestic.
articles.abstract: Officials were not prepared to say whether the attack was the act of a lone and troubled man or connected to terrorist groups, foreign or domestic.
articles.lead_paragraph: KILLEEN, Tex.  On Wednesday and Thursday, Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan seemed in a hurry to give his worldly belongings to a neighbor. First a Koran. Then bags of vegetables. Finally a mattress, clothing and odds and ends from his bare one-room flat.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and James Dao
